prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friends wedding.
So my best friend (lets call her G) has decided to have her wedding, that's awesome and I'm happy she found the one. 

The issue is G never sent out save the dates, meaning last week we got the actual wedding invitations for a wedding that is happening in 1 month.  

It will be at her grandmother's Ranch and it seems like a pretty nice wedding. 

here is where the issue started. 

a few months ago me and 3 friends decided to plan a trip to Australia to backpack/sightsee for 2 weeks, the trip starts 2 days before the wedding so we can't go. G knew about the trip as we invited her but I'm geussing she forgot. 
she is mad at all of us for not just cancelling the trip and being at her wedding. 

all of us are not super rich so this would be a huge loss if we cancelled the trip. (so we are not) 

I also want to add that she invited 50 people, I asked. and only 20 can make it as she gave 1 month notice. 

she is flipping her shit and acting like we should drop everything for her. 

AITA for not just cancelling my 2 week trip to go to her wedding? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to figure this out. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for not attending their best friend's wedding. Let's break down the details.

First, the friend (G) didn't send save-the-dates and only sent invitations a month before the wedding. The author and three friends had planned a trip to Australia that starts two days before the wedding. They had invited G to the trip, but she forgot about it. The author is now being criticized by G for not canceling the trip. The author mentions that the trip is expensive, so canceling would be a big loss. Also, G invited 50 people, but only 20 can make it due to the short notice.

So, the main points are: G gave short notice, the trip was planned in advance and involves money, and the author had already informed G about the trip. The author is being accused of not prioritizing the wedding, but G's lack of planning seems to be a factor here. 

Is the author at fault? Well, friends usually expect some level of presence at big events like weddings, but if the planning was done responsibly and the friend didn't communicate properly, maybe the fault isn't entirely on the author. The author tried to include G in their plans and had to make a choice based on financial constraints. G's reaction seems harsh given her own role in the short notice. So I think the answer is B, the author isn't in the wrong here.
